repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
add border in completion window. config it by using `completepopup` option. 
option in picture is `set completepopup=border:rounded,title:Omnifunc,title_pos:center`

![image](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/41671631/14b66768-46ab-421c-904a-206cfa578dd0)




Fix #15551

comment_data.body: if possible we should reuse most of `win_redr_border` . It is only called in one place, so the window specific parts could be moved out and instead have something like `grid_draw_border` which takes `grid` and inner height/width as parameters.

## Call to function with fewer arguments than declared parameters

This call has fewer arguments than required by [parse_completepopup](1).

[Show more details](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/security/code-scanning/49)

comment_data.body: A bit of a nit, but for most other options (like 'completeopt') we don't use underscores, so I think this should be `titlepos` (and similarly for `footerpos`).
Please mention about the default `align` value. I guess it is ~`item`~ `menu`.

comment_regular_data.body:
mostly finished. confused on the format of custom border characters..does this is valid ? afaik vim options do not have this way of use array nested.

```
set completepopup=border:[ ["+", "MyBorder"], ["-", "MyBorder"], ["+", "MyBorder"], ["|", "MyBorder"], ["+", "MyBorder"], ["-", "MyBorder"], ["+", "MyBorder"], ["|", "MyBorder"] ]
```

Is it necessary to add different borders for pum and info like add `pum_border` and `info_border` . if border set then pum and info both use `border` otherwise pum use `pum_border` info use `info_border`. :thinking:

@glepnir, if I understand correctly, `title` and `footer` in the suggested 'completepopup' design set an actual title string shown in the window. How is it intended to actually be used? In particular:
- Is title used by default with the built-in completion sources (like omnifunc, paths, lines, etc.)? Because if not and users have to set it manually (like `title:Omnifunc` in the original comment), then a) how are they supposed to *set* it (via remapping all `<C-x>...` mappings, or something else?); and b) how are they supposed to *unset* it (so that mismatched title is not shown with different source)?
- Built-in completion can also be triggered via `complete()`. Is the intended way of utilizing title by updating 'completepopup' option? If so, then what is the intended way to unset it later?

Maybe it would be better to have 'title' and 'footer' be boolean to represent whether a (some dedicated) title should be shown if there is a border? This way built-in sources can provide their own titles while `complete()` would require a third `opts` argument (if possible).

1. Currently there is no matching default completion mode.  can be added. if has border and is default completion mode 
    set defualt title lik path keyword etc.
3. Keep the original value before complete and restore it in ondone ? maybe

> * Currently there is no matching default completion mode.  can be added. if has border and is default completion mode
>   set defualt title lik path keyword etc.

To me this sounds cleaner from the user's view. At the same time this makes string 'title' and 'footer' values somewhat questionable.

> * Keep the original value before complete and restore it in ondone ? maybe

Sure, yet this sounds somewhat complicated.

I think that actual string values of title and footer are more "temporary" data that actually describes the *source* of completion and not the completion popup as a whole. So maybe it is better to somehow be a part of completion source definition? And instead use something like boolean `showtitle` and `showfooter` which would define whether a user *wants* title and footer to be shown?
I will add the default completion mode title support first and then think about the second question more carefully 🤔

> mostly finished. confused on the format of custom border characters..does this is valid ? afaik vim options do not have this way of use array nested.
> 
> ```
> set completepopup=border:[ ["+", "MyBorder"], ["-", "MyBorder"], ["+", "MyBorder"], ["|", "MyBorder"], ["+", "MyBorder"], ["-", "MyBorder"], ["+", "MyBorder"], ["|", "MyBorder"] ]
> ```

I was just trying this out, and was wondering if this was implemented yet in some way? I couldn't manage to make a custom border work. If not implemented yet, sorry for commenting
There are plans to implement this form of support in option . But it's not here :) currently just some string value which defined in nvim_open_win

Is it possible and related to this PR to enable separate settings for cmdline and Insert mode menu?
yes.  just check `State == MODE_CMDLINE` to detect in cmdline ..  When in cmdline it should be called something with wild prefix.. like `wildpopup` ?

> yes. just check `State == MODE_CMDLINE` to detect in cmdline .. When in cmdline it should be called something with wild prefix.. like `wildpopup` ?

It would be nice to have it almost here. IIRC `vim.ui_attach(ns, {ext_popupmenu = true},` didn't allow such separation (to, for example, touch only insert mode menu).
get mode in callback of ui_attach does not make sense ?

It's not clear for me (and documented in `:h vim.ui_attach()`, along with its example) what to do in the callback `if vim.fn.mode() == 'c'` to keep only cmdline menu untouched. 

Please possibly mark it as offtopic. 

edit: `vim.ui_detach()` on `CmdlineEnter` seems to be known workaround.

should works now thanks for report 👍
'completepopup' is a vim option, so presumably this address various vim patches. The commit messages should have `vim-patch:...` items.

> should works now thanks for report 👍

Now manual tests for both modes show me perfect positioning :rocket:


Looking at those screenshots I realized that there might need to be a new highlight group for this. Because `FloatBorder` is designed to be used with floating windows and their `NormalFloat` as base. As having `Pmenu` being different to floating windows is quite common (and is present in default color scheme), there would be no way for border to have the same background as popup.

Something like `PmenuBorder`, maybe? Or maybe even together with `PmenuTitle`?
@glepnir would it be possible to resolve conflict with #30246 while both PRs are not merged? I use it to avoid errors described there.
@przepompownia  I can rebase and fix confict no worry.
@glepnir thank you for resolving conflict. There is yet another one but only in the description of test set.

a new implementation of title. we don't need any extra fields to specify the title. because everything can be done in the script.dynamically set the title accroding `:help comp_info_mode` which can get in `complete_info`

```vimscript
let s:has_set = v:false
funct Set_info()
  let comp_info = complete_info()
  let completepopup_value = &completepopup
  let val = matchstr(&completepopup, 'title:\s*\zs[^,]*')
  let mode = comp_info['mode']
  if (empty(val) || val != mode) && !empty(mode) && !s:has_set
    " there will update the title of pum border
    execute 'set completepopup+=title:' . comp_info['mode']
    let s:has_set = v:true
  endif

  --other codes
endfunc
autocmd CompleteChanged * call Set_info()
```

> a new implementation of title. we don't need any extra fields to specify the title. because everything can be done in the script.dynamically set the title accroding `:help comp_info_mode` which can get in `complete_info`

Would you mind clarifying a bit about when and who do you suggest to use this code?

Is it for regular users who just want to see title for built-in completion? If yes, then it seems *too* complicated for the effect it provides.

Is it for plugin authors who wish to provide custom completion (for example, with `vim.fn.complete()`)? If yes, then it doesn't seem to do that.

As far as I understand, [this](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25541#issuecomment-2317437637) and [this](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25541#issuecomment-2317516787) comments are still relevant.

My idea is to put this code in the doc. If you want to set dynamic title, you can do it. You can also hard code the title. It depends on the requirement. If you just want to update the title dynamically, then you only need a few lines of code in your configuration file.

> Is it for plugin authors who wish to provide custom completion (for example, with vim.fn.complete())? If yes, then it doesn't seem to do that.

i don't understat what you mean here . if from `complete` the mode is `eval` you can't custom it ? `if mode == eval` generate a title and update the completepopup option it will update the title of pum border.

> My idea is to put this code in the doc. If you want to set dynamic title, you can do it. You can also hard code the title. It depends on the requirement. If you just want to update the title dynamically, then you only need a few lines of code in your configuration file.

For me the most reasonable requirements from a user that wants to see title from built-in popup menus are the following:
- Enable some option to register that user wants to see titles. For example, 'showtitle' flag in 'completeopt'. Another approach is for 'showtitle' to be a string indicating position ('left', 'right', 'center').
- If user types keys for built-in completion (for example, `<C-x><C-l>`), the popup shows the title for specific source ("Whole line" in this case; and not a "whole_line").
- If *plugin author* wants to show results via built-in popup menu (i.e. via `vim.fn.complete()`), they can set the title *somehow*. For example, as an extra entry in `opts` dictionary (requires changing `complete()` signature) or as `vim.api.nvim__complete_set(0, { title = 'My completion' })`.

Requiring to add at least 13 lines of Vimscript *just to see title* in my opinion is not a user-friendly approach. Switching to 'showtitle' and 'showfooter' entries (each with 'left', 'center', 'right' possible values) significantly reduces the burden on the user while also reducing maintenance for this particular option.

some point sounds reasonable. It reduces the burden on ordinary users. `__complet_set_info` not a good place because it most use on a async request for info of a complete-item.  adding a parameter to complete is one way. I'm thinking about it for a while

> Enable some option to register that user wants to see titles. For example, 'showtitle' flag in 'completeopt'. Another approach is for 'showtitle' to be a string indicating position ('left', 'right', 'center').

about this point so showfooter is also defined similarly?  how do we define the string for footer?

> about this point so showfooter is also defined similarly? how do we define the string for footer?

In my mind, both title and footer are reasonable to be treated in exactly the same way:
- Allow `showfooter` option in 'completeopt' with possible values of 'left', 'center', 'right'.
- Built-in completion popups define no footer.
- Custom completions from plugins need to have some mechanism of setting/updating both title and footer in completion popup (which will be only shown if there is 'showtitle' / 'showfooter' option in 'completeopt').

During writing this, I got some other idea: maybe do not allow setting custom footer in favor of always the same "current/total" indicator of item number. So that it will show current item number and total number of completion items *at this particular stage* (not the one that `complete_info()` can provide). It would still be shown and configured behind 'showfooter=left|center|right' option. But that is more a suggestion/idea, as I can not thing about any other useful ways of utilizing footer specifically in completion popup.
so `footer` just show count and current select index , then `showfooter=on/off`

> so `footer` just show count and current select index , then `showfooter=on/off`

I mean, it is one of the approaches, yes. But `showfooter` can still be 'left|center|right': this both reuses the same approach as with title with the benefit of allowing small configuration.

Just to be clear, these are more or less my thoughts about what I as a user (and plugin developer who utilizes built-in popups) would like to see here :)
I understand what you mean. left right center replaces on. If want disable footer just don't set it.

It's not easy for me too, but as a side effect I found something similar.

```sh
mkdir test && cd test && git init && touch init.lua && git add init.lua

```
Fill in `init.lua` with 

```lua
local thisInitFile = debug.getinfo(1).source:match('@?(.*)')
local cwd = vim.fs.dirname(thisInitFile)
local appname = vim.env.NVIM_APPNAME or 'nvim'

vim.env.XDG_CONFIG_HOME = cwd
vim.env.XDG_DATA_HOME = vim.fs.joinpath(cwd, '.xdg', 'data')
vim.env.XDG_STATE_HOME = vim.fs.joinpath(cwd, '.xdg', 'state')
vim.env.XDG_CACHE_HOME = vim.fs.joinpath(cwd, '.xdg', 'cache')
vim.fn.mkdir(vim.fs.joinpath(vim.env.XDG_CACHE_HOME, appname), 'p')
local stdPathConfig = vim.fn.stdpath('config')

vim.opt.runtimepath:prepend(stdPathConfig)
vim.opt.packpath:prepend(stdPathConfig)

local function gitClone(url, installPath, branch)
  if vim.fn.isdirectory(installPath) ~= 0 then
    return
  end

  local command = {'git', 'clone', '--', url, installPath}
  if branch then
    table.insert(command, 3, '--branch')
    table.insert(command, 4, branch)
  end

  vim.notify(('Cloning %s dependency into %s...'):format(url, installPath), vim.log.levels.INFO, {})
  local sysObj = vim.system(command, {}):wait()
  if sysObj.code ~= 0 then
    error(sysObj.stderr)
  end
  vim.notify(sysObj.stdout)
  vim.notify(sysObj.stderr, vim.log.levels.WARN)
end

local pluginsPath = vim.fs.joinpath(cwd, 'nvim/pack/plugins/opt')
vim.fn.mkdir(pluginsPath, 'p')
pluginsPath = vim.uv.fs_realpath(pluginsPath)

--- @type table<string, {url:string, branch: string?}>
local plugins = {
  ['lualine'] = {url = 'https://github.com/nvim-lualine/lualine.nvim'},
}

for name, repo in pairs(plugins) do
  local installPath = vim.fs.joinpath(pluginsPath, name)
  gitClone(repo.url, installPath, repo.branch)
  vim.cmd.packadd({args = {name}, bang = true})
end

local function init()
  vim.go.completepopup = 'border:rounded'
  vim.go.completeopt = 'noinsert,menuone'
  vim.api.nvim_feedkeys(vim.keycode('Gz-3<C-e>orou'), 'n', false)
  vim.schedule(function ()
    vim.api.nvim_feedkeys(vim.keycode('<C-n>'), 'i', false)
  end)
end

vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('UIEnter', {
  once = true,
  callback = init,
})

require('lualine').setup({
  sections = {
    lualine_b = {
      'diff',
    },
  },
})
```
Assuming unstaged changes in `init.lua` run
- `nvim --clean -u init.lua init.lua`

@przepompownia emm it's better remove lualine.... and this thread a bit long so if have a useful minial you can send to me in element irc

This is the minimal `init.lua` for the empty border:

```lua
vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('UIEnter', {
  callback = function ()
    vim.o.lines = 10
    vim.go.completepopup = 'border:rounded'
    vim.go.completeopt = 'noinsert,menuone'
    vim.api.nvim_feedkeys(vim.keycode('Gz-3<C-e>orou'), 'n', false)
    vim.schedule(function ()
      vim.api.nvim_feedkeys(vim.keycode('<C-n>'), 'i', false)
    end)
  end,
})

vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('ModeChanged', {callback = vim.schedule_wrap(function ()
  vim.cmd('highlight! xxxx guifg=#eef1f8 guibg=#504945')
end)})
```
`nvim --clean -u init.lua init.lua`

Late to the party here, but is there something similar for styling the "popup info" window (when a completion item has the "info" property set)? I have not been able to find the right verbiage in docs / gh PRs / comments in the past, so when I say "popup info" window I am talking about this in red in my screenshot. The window that is in place of `preview` when you add `popup` to the `completeopt` option. Typically it is very hard to see / distinguish from the rest of the editor wen cycling through completion items.

Thanks!
